title: mysterious abandoned mansion
story: Property millionaire Athanasios Tachmintzis, , lived in the huge house near King’s Langley, Herts, before disappearing more than three years ago.Pictures emerged on Monday showing the faded glory of the abandoned mansion left to rot after the owners seemingly left in a hurry, maybe even in the middle of the night.Neighbours have wondered what caused Mr Tachmintzis to flee the house, leaving furniture, ornaments, designers clothes and even a game of chess on the table.A watch stuck in time was seen on a bedside table, while designer clothes bearing the labels Yves St Laurent, Gucci and Louis Vuitton were stacked up on rails in a bedroom.Empty fish tanks were left lined up in a hallway - while a dishwasher stacked with plates had not been unloaded.A Japanese-theme piano takes pride of place in one of the rooms with the music left out ready to play, while stacks of china were sitting on a living room table next to the sofas.In his huge bathroom, there is a Jacuzzi-style tub with half-used shampoo and conditioner bottles.Amazingly, a potted plant is still alive on a windowsill next to a telescope lined up ready for its owner to look at the night sky.A utility room has a snooker table and outside, four or five cars - including a rusted Bentley - lie in overgrown grass.According to MailOnline, villagers said the dad-of-five lived there for around  years before suddenly vanishing.They said he lived there with his daughters and at least one of his sons.Mr Tachmintzis’ we Sharon, who was born in North Wales, died aged  in .The pair were married for  years and had three sons Alexis, , Nicholas, , and -year-old Paul. They had two daughters Kiristiana, , and Alicia, .It is believed Mr Tachmintzis was so concerned about security he kept Dobermans as guard dogs and employed staff to stand on his gate.One neighbour told MailOnline: “I ride my horse down the road every day and all of a sudden I realised around three years ago that the people there had just disappeared.“I just thought at first that they had gone away somewhere and would then come back – but nobody did. It is most strange.“At first the gates were just shut and then a padlock and chain appeared on them. You could just see the grass getting longer and longer and growing around the cars.“Nobody around here has a clue what happened to them and why they just upped and left. It is a real mystery.“They obviously had loads of money because it is a big house. There were always lots of comings and goings with dferent people going in and out.“They used to have up to three Dobermans. His two daughters would walk them, and sometimes the cleaner would take them out, but they were too big for her to handle and she had to stop.“One day around six-years-ago, this guy in his s came out and said that his dogs had gone missing and he askedwe had seen them, but we hadnt.“The girls were dark haired and very pretty. I think they used to go to a local health club and gym.”Another villager said he heard Mr Tachmintzis made a huge deal involving a luxury property on the exclusive Sandbanks resort in Dorset.They said: “I believe his we had cancer and died several years ago.“He also had a housekeeper, but she left suddenly. It is certainly very odd. Nobody knows what caused them to leave the house, seemingly never to .”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: wuhan bans sale of bat meat markets coronavirus
story: WUHAN has finally banned the sale of bats and other wild animal meat amid fears coronavirus originated in one of the citys bizarre food markets.The Chinese citys municipal government today announced a comprehensive ban on eating all wild animals and the hunting and trading of wildle.It released a list of strict new rules which will come into immediate effect and will last for at least the next five years.According to the official statement, there will be a ban on the sale and eating of terrestrial wild animals that are both in the wild or bred for the dinner table for dishes like bat soup.Wuhan also announced a complete ban on the hunting of wild animals stating the whole city is now a wildle sanctuary.There will also be prohibitions on breeding aquatic wild animals - like frogs-  for eating and bans on wildle trading in markets and online.This notice shall come into force on the date of promulgation and shall be valid for five years, the the statement read.News of the ban was welcomed by Boris Johnsons fiancee Carrie Symonds who tweeted: Lets hope this remains the case.Wuhan is now the fourth Chinese city to outlaw dangerous practice of selling wild animals for food.The World Health Organisation has previously pointed the finger at the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market in the city for the killer outbreak.It claimed many of the first virus victims were stall owners, employees or regular shoppers.The WHO said tests on samples indicated it was the source of the outbreak or had “played a role in the initial amplication”.The Huanan market had a wild animal section where live and slaughtered species were sold for food including snakes, frogs, beavers, porcupines and even baby crocodiles.Close interactions with wild animals have caused numerous disease outbreaks in humans including Ebola, Sars and HIV.Viruses can sp easilyanimals in markets are sick or kept in dirty, cramped conditions, such as in stacked cages.When animals are under duress, viral pathogens can intermingle, swap bits of their genetic code, and possibly mutate in ways that make them more transmissible between species.In the case of respiratory diseases -  like Covid- - the virus can jump to food handlers or shoppers through exposure to an animal’s bodily fluids.Early studies showed the new strain of coronavirus did originate in bats, but scientists have been trying to find which animal then transferred it onto humans.Dferent studies have so-far linked pangolins, stray dogs and snakes to the cause of the deadly outbreak which has so far claimed more than , lives.The search for the source of the virus has become more complex since US-China relations have soured following President Trumps claim it originated in a lab.Mr Trump has repeatedly told the media he has evidence  the virus came from the Wuhan Institute of Virology.But China has responded to these allegations with its own conspiracy theory asserting that American soldiers may have been responsible for the outbreak.News of the ban comes as it is revealed more than , people in Wuhan may have been infected by Covid-.The shock figure comes after an antibody sampling showed a positive rate of five to six per cent in the city.With a population of  million in Wuhan, the findings suggest that up half a million people in the city could have already been struck down.Meanwhile the under-fire city has already screened more than half of its population - including doing half a million tests in just one day this week.Figures released by the Wuhan Health Commission showed a staggering , nucleic acid tests were carried out on Monday.The testing figure was more than the , conducted a day earlier as part of the health authoritys ambitious campaign to test every single one of its residents by th May.Described as a -day battle, the mass testing initiative started on th May, with the central municipal government ordering all  of its districts to come up with their own way to test every resident within its borders.Millions have been queuing inside gated communities, where parks and public squares are being used as assembly points and makesht swabbing stations.Each COVID- test takes about three minutes, while the procedure is free to the public, officials said.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits sneak back to pub takeaways
story: THIRSTY Brits are back on the booze after crafty pub owners exposed a lockdown loophole to serve punters.Bars across the UK are taking advantage of an easing in the rules which allows them to serve drinks in takeaway glasses and bottles.The move, and sizzling temperatures, led to thousands of Brits doing what they love most - enjoying a cheeky drink with their mates.Pictures posted on social media show people downing their first drinks from their locals since , pubs and bars were closed on March .Other pictures featured couples sharing drinks in the sunshine and drinkers supping from plastic pub glasses in back gardens.And queues were seen forming outside one bar in Bournemouth selling takeaway booze.One photo showed a punter showing off his pint outside the Old Kings Head in Shoreditch, London as temperatures topped F.Fred Johnson posted a photo with the words: Local pub doing takeaway. First drink out since lockdown.While Fraser Coleman wrote: Stuck in the garden with a takeaway beer from the Duke of Wellington.The pictures emerged as ministers raised the prospect that pub restrictions could be eased in July allowing some to reopen for summer.However, any opening will be limited at first to those larger venues with plenty of outside space.“We are already working with the hospitality and pub sector to identy what social distancing measures they might be able to put in place to make that work,” revealed Mr Eustice. “As the prime minister has outlined, we intend that the hospitality sector, including pubs, would be able to tentatively start gradually opening, hopefully during the month of July — subject to the epidemiology supporting such a move.”And Jonathan Neame, chief executive of Shepherd Neame, told The Financial Times keeping two metres apart would be “profoundly challenging” to the industry.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: torso suitcase suspect pictured first time
story: Dad-of-two Mahesh Sorathiya, , from Wolverhampton was charged with assisting an offender and granted bail after Phoenix Netts remains were found in the Forest of Dean.Gareeca Conita Gordon, , who lived at the same seven-bed refuge in Birmingham as Phoenix, , has been charged with murder after the grim discovery was made last week.Sorathiya was seen today at Wolverhampton central police station to sign on under his strict bail conditions and a provisional trial date has been set for November  this year.Today, the victims ex-boyfriend described her as kind and quiet who had struggled with the trauma of a previous sexual assault.Meanwhile, Phoenixs friend from university - named Fawn - described the young woman as someone who would give you her last penny.She told the MailOnline: It makes me sick that somebody could kill her and then cut her body up.Phoenix was a kind and considerate woman.We had great times at university. But she did have mental health issues and when I spoke to her about eight months ago on Facebook, she wasn’t in a good place.But I am so saddened at what has happened to her.Tragically, the young womans body was found by Gloucestershire Police last Tuesday night after the driver of a Vauxhall was spotted with concerns they were flouting the coronavirus lockdown.Officers discovered the body parts stuffed in two suitcases. It is understood there had been attempts to burn the remains.Prosecutor James Ward QC told the court this week: When they opened the suitcases, the police said it smelled of barbecue and the smell was sickening from the decomposition.The ex-boyfriend of Phoenix said today that he had gone to Canterbury Christ Church University with her between  and  where she had trained to become a paramedic - but she didnt graduate.He told the Mail Online: She told me and one other friend of hers that she had been raped by a drug dealer.Phoenix was kind and quiet, but also vulnerable. She didn’t have a great childhood after her parents had split up. I was ignorant to peoples’ mental health at the time, so I wouldn’t have been able to analyse then as I can now.But she seemed damaged, and rightly so, by the trauma she went through. I don’t know which way her le went after we split up, but it clearly went south.She never expressed any interest in kids or getting married.The Times today revealed Gordon, , lived in the room opposite to Phoenix in the seven-bedroom terraced property in Lozells.It is understood Phoenix had grown up in Croydon, south London before relocating to the Midlands - later moving into the womens refuge late last year.Her family issued an emotional statement in response to her tragic death on May .It read: “As a family we are devastated with what has happened to Phoenix.“We have family and good friends supporting us and our thanks go out to all of them.“We would also like to thank all the police officers involved in the investigation for their hard work and sensitivity.Neighbour Wahidur Rahman, , said: Phoenix was a really nice young girl. She was lovely.I thought something might have happened to her because I hadn’t seen her in a while.Detective Chief Inspector Scott Grfiths from our homicide team said: “Firstly, I’d like to offer my sincere condolences to Phoenix’s family.“We’ve worked closely with colleagues at Gloucestershire over the past week and our investigation continues at pace.“We’d urge anyone with any information about the tragic loss of Phoenix’s le to get in touch with us.

title: britain first leader paul golding
story: Golding, , was stopped at Heathrow Airport on October  last year on his way back from Moscow by officers from the politan Police.He refused to give the pin codes for an iPhone and Apple computer and was later charged with wilfully refusing to comply with a duty under Schedule  of the Terrorism Act.Golding, the leader of the far-right political group, denied the charge but was found guilty of the offence following a trial at Westminster Magistrates Court in London on Wednesday.Chief magistrate Emma Arbuthnot ruled there was no doubt that Golding had failed to comply with requests for information, despite his obligations being explained to him and being warned over and over thathe did not he risked arrest.She handed Golding a conditional discharge for nine months and ordered him to pay a £ surcharge and £ in costs.Ms Arbuthnot said Golding had been lawfully questioned and that under Schedule  there had been no requirement for reasonable suspicion for the stop.PC Rory OConnor, a borders officer with the Met who questioned Golding, told the court that Schedule  enables accredited officers to speak to people in order to make a determination of whether they are or have been concerned in the commission, preparation or instigation of acts of terrorism.The officer explained that it also permitted police to interrogate, search and detain anyone for up to six hours at UK ports.He said he had cause to examine Golding under the legislation and recalled him being initially agitated and clearly angry at being stopped, with him shouting at officers.Prosecutor Samuel Main said that for nearly three hours Golding was questioned about his activities in Russia after flying out with two others on October .The court heard that Golding said he was on a purely political trip after establishing friendships in Russia during an international congress on an earlier date.He told officers that he had ed to the country under the invitation of the Liberal Democratic Party of Russia , which he described as a right wing, conservative, patriotic group who were not extreme.English Defence League founder Tommy Robinson, whose real name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon, watched the proceedings in the courts socially distanced public gallery.Over the course of his three-day trip, Golding gave interviews to the media, met members of the LDPR and visited the Russian parliament, Mr Main said.He also visited Moscows Red Square and laid a wreath at the tomb of the unknown soldier.In audio recording of the interview played in court, Golding said the request for his pin codes was wildly inappropriate, completely unjustied, and was a political witch hunt.Mr Main said he told officers they hadnt asked him about terrorism or criminality and he was simply a politician.Britain First was deregistered as a political party in November .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: sun says steve coogan greed furlough
story: How does a man worth £million defend sponging off taxpayers to fund the bulk of his laid-off housekeeper and gardener’s salaries  Especially a man so very keen to judge the morality of others It’s not illegal. But the Government furlough system was set up as a fallback to keep people in jobs, not to protect the wealth of multi-millionaires or billionaires by paying their staff for them.Many families who can afford cleaners have dug deep to keep them solvent during this crisis. They have not demanded the public bail them out.Coogan could pay his staff in full without denting even a fraction of the interest on his riches. Instead he chose to make taxpayers do it.That’s greed, all right. As for the comic’s risible claim that “I don’t get anything for free”, it’s not true now, is it It is equally repugnant that Foxtons magnate Jon Hunt has kept his £.billion dry by getting the public to pay his  furloughed country club workers.At least Victoria Beckham changed her mind after belatedly realising from the public outcry how wrong it was for a woman as rich as she is to make a claim.The UK faces a recession of unprecedented scale, with millions unemployed and the Treasury’s depleted coffers struggling to keep us afloat.Let us never forget those mega-rich celebrity hypocrites who abused the State’s generosity during the Covid crisis and brought ordinary people’s ruin even closer.BORIS Johnson must show stronger leadership over getting kids back to school.The softening-up of the June  restart date for primaries betrays a man cowed by the storm the unions whipped up.He must remember that they are led by Corbynites engaging in a political war against the Brexit-backing Tory Government which they detest for destroying their dreams last December.But we do agree with the unions on one thing. If the advice from Sage’s scientists is that ing to school is safe, publish it in full.Then the public, the teachers and their unions can see it.The PM must then order schools to , once they have finalised social distancing measures.If the NEU wants to strike, it can ­ballot members.If local councils refuse to open schools, the Government MUST sanction them. And Sir Keir Starmer’s Labour must decide whether to side with the hard-Left over working people.Boris’s drt is worrying. This matter could barely be more urgent.It is about the educational and mental wellbeing of our children, especially the most disadvantaged, and the ability of parents toto work and rebuild our shattered economy.Get a grip on it, PM.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus shows we got out just in time now someone switch the eu ventilator off
story: But there’s one thing the pandemic has made absolutely clear — we were right, beyond all doubt, to leave the European Union.The EU is in desperate trouble. Its vast bureaucratic institutions were utterly unable to react to the threat of the virus.So the inidual countries did it all for themselves. Each following a dferent policy. When the moment came, the EU was found wanting. Lethargic, hopeless and riven with internal dispute.There is fury in Spain that the EUwon’t bung them loads of money for being badly hit by the virus.It’s the same in Italy, where  per cent of the population now want to LEAVE the EU. The country that was usually one of the EU’s biggest cheerleaders.A disillusion with the EU is spreading across the continent.People are beginning to see that it’s a good thing to have control of your borders. And that the best way of controlling those borders is through a nation state.The Greeks have been trying to contain a mass influx of refugees from Turkey — and getting no help from the EU in the process. Some senior EU politicians fear that the virus could kill off the EU altogether. Right now it’s on a ventilator and looking very sorry for itself.We can only hope — for the good of our European friends — that someone switches that ventilator off.Once we all emerge from lockdown there will be a financial price to pay. Our economy — the world’s economy — has taken a hell of a battering.But the good news is that we will be in with a much better chance of a full recovery than the EU bloc.From  you will no longer have to pay tarfs on a vast range of goods imported from beyond Europe.I suspect it will lead to a consumer bonanza — which is just what we want. Washing machines, freezers, women’s sanitary products, bicycle inner tubes, Christmas trees — the list of stuff which will be cheaper is almost endless.It’s true thatthe EU refuses to soften its stance about a trade deal with us, then we’ll pay more for cars made on the continent.But even that might have its upside. It will encourage people to buy British. Last year Brits bought only , cars that had been manufactured in the UK. The majority of cars were bought from German plants. Your loss, Germany.The EU negotiators are still being intransigent. They still think they can bully this country.Michael Gove has told them to get real. Sort out an acceptable trade deal for the good of the entire European economy.But eventhey don’t — evenreality fails to establish itself inside their closed minds— it will be the EU that loses out.It wouldn’t surprise me hugelyCovid- outlasted the European Union, frankly. We should all breathe a sigh of relief that we got the hell out of that helpless institution.Just in time.I WONDERCovid- will see an end to hard cash  My local shopkeepers tell me that almost no transactions in the past two months have been paid in cash. It’s all done by card.I’ve had the same  quid in my pocket that was there on March .I bet we don’t go back to paying in cash once this is over. Queuing for ages behind some addled berk at the ATM who is incapable of pressing the right buttons. Cash is going the way of the dinosaurs.And it’s not too far of a stretch to suggest that offices might be on their way out, either. Hugely expensive things to run, offices. And the original reason we had them was to store paper – files and so on. Don’t really need that any more, do we  People have discovered that working from home has many benefits. Not least the pleasure of avoiding pointless meetings with idiots.And for those who feel the need to get away from their families on a daily basis there’s “co-working environments”, or “the park with a load of booze”, as I like to call it.MOST lady slebs are busy during lockdown taking pictures of themselves wearing almost no clothes.Either to advertise products nobody really wants or to advertise themselves. For which many thanks, girls.Scarcely a day goes by without one of them taking a perfectly natural selfie of herself with hardly any clothes on, pouting at the camera like a trout with a botched facelt.Model Rosie Huntington-Whiteley has gone a stage further and posted pics of herself taken  years ago. Just in case we’d forgotten.I might get in on the act. Next week I’ll take a selfie wearing a leather thong and nipple clamps, advertising my new skincare product made from vole’s urine.Watch this space.I’m not so sure. Boredom is a greatly underrated virtue. It makes you get off your backside and do something. And our kids have been bored senseless for two months now.You never know, this break might do the kids some good. Fire their imaginations or something.And better still – it means they’re not having left-wing drivel drilled into their heads by the teachers…THE English Football League is in a right old mess.None of its three isions can agree what to do about finishing the season.The clubs in the lowest tier, ision two, have voted to end the season immediately. Those in the Championship want to finish the season, while League One clubs haven’t a clue.There’s talk of Coventry and Rotherham being promoted and a play-off between the next EIGHT clubs.I know a lot of money is at stake. I know the league has signed big deals with the broad- casters. But the sensible thing surely would have been to call the season null and void, across all three isions.Those of us who, like me, support clubs who had a chance of promotion will get over our disappointment.There are more important things than football.So let’s look at Sweden. It became the country with the highest death rate per capita from Covid- in Europe during thesevendays to May .The lockdown has unquestionably saved lives.LAST Friday night I was called  times in the space of an hour by the SAME NUMBER.What’s more, my phone told me the call was coming from Tajikistan. But every time I tried to answer, the caller hung up. That’s totally unfair.I have never in my le spoken to a person from Tajikistan. And I would very much like to do so. It might be interesting.I’m sure it was a criminal of some kind, but that’s not the point.I wanted to knowmy caller was a member of the mysterious Yaghnobi people, who live in the mountains in the north of the country, with their many goats. That would have been exciting.I might start ringing up numbers in Tajikistan indiscriminately. And then move on to Kyrgyzstan.That’s what lockdown does to you.For this they have been attacked by “human rights activists”.Perhaps.But not by the people of Hungary, who fully agree with this measure.Much as I suspect people would over here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cops last known cctv image tesco
story: The CCTV still shows Louise Smith at a Tesco supermarket the night before she disappeared from her home in Havant, Hants, on VE Day.Louse was last seen around midday on May  after telling pals she was popping out briefly.She was due tohome to spend the weekend with her boyfriend, who had come over to stay.Detectives managed to trace her mobile phone to a skate park before it was switched off two hours later.Cops have released CCTV of Louise captured at a Tescostore on Greywell Road that she visited around .pm on May .Officers hunting for the missing youngster hope the photos will jog someones memory.A man and woman, both , were arrested on suspicion of kidnap last Friday have now been released on bail.Volunteers from the Isle of Wight Search and Rescue team have also joined the hunt in Hampshire, Berkshire, Sussex and Surrey.After her phone was switched off around pm on that day, family had said, Louise had not been seen or heard from despite constant door-to-door inquiries being carried out by police.Louise is described as: white, around ft ins tall, slim, and straight, black, shoulder- hair.Detectives urged residents in Leigh Park to check their CCTV in case the schooolgirl appears on it.A spokesman for Hampshire Constabulary said:  As part of our ongoing inquiries to find Louise, we are not only trying to trace her movements since this time, but also in the previous  hours, so that we have a clear understanding of where she had been and who she may have spoken to.We know she was in the Tescostore, in Greywell Road, shortly before .pm the night before she was reported missing, Thursday May , and we are today able to share that image with you, in the hope it may jog your memory.Perhaps you saw her on Thursday May , either before or after she was in the store Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk weather forecast lockdown hottest day
story: Temperatures could reach C again in the south of the UK as warmer weather continues, while the east of England will likely be hit with heavy rain.Sunseekers flocked to beaches and beauty spots across the UK yesterday as England, Scotland and Wales all had their hottest days of  so far.Across the country, sunbathers made the most of their new-found freedom and the warmer weather following the easing of lockdown restrictions - but many forgot about coronavirus social distancing.The hottest spot in the UK on Wednesday was Santon Downham in Suffolk, which saw temperatures climb to .C.Scotland also saw its warmest day of , with .C recorded in Aviemore in the Highlands.Yesterdays scorching temperatures are set to carry over into today.Most of the UK will enjoy temperatures in mid-s, with areas around London most likely to reach C.But the South East, East Anglia, Kent and London may also see thundery showers, heavy rain and thunder and lighting this afternoon.A Met Office spokeswoman said: One or two showers could break out through the morning into the afternoon, and again with the risk of thunder.And yes, through the afternoon you could see the odd isolated heavier bursts.On Friday, a deep area of low pressure is due to arrive on the North West of the UK, bringing heavy rain and the risk of severe gales, with highs of C towards the South East.Scotland should see temperatures in the high teens, with similar temperatures in the east and north east of England on Friday.Over the weekend, the weather will be drier, with winds towards the north and blustery further south on Saturday, and temperatures rising to around C in Birmingham.But by Sunday most southern parts will have a fine day, with Monday set for more sunny weather.The Met Office said: By Monday temperatures should start to rise again.They added: There will be high or very high levels of UV at times over the weekend.If you do have to go out for whatever reason, do be aware you may have to protect yourself from the sun.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. the agreement.“Those who work in the NHS or those who work in care homes are exempt from the conditions.”The telly host asked: “What about teachers, police officers, firefighters  They are all paying title: sturgeons roadmap easing lockdown today
story: NICOLA Sturgeon will set out a four-phase blueprint for Scotland to begin easing lockdown restrictions today.Scotland has now been in full lockdown for almost three months and has refused to follow the Prime Ministers relaxation of restrictions last week.Ms Sturgeon will make her speech at .pm today, after she said she did not have confidence in Boris Johnsons decision to allow Brits more freedom.The Scottish leader has insisted all the evidence pointed towards having to continue with the same rules and while England shted towards a stay alert message, Scotland continued stay-at-home orders.Ms Sturgeon was highly critical of the new stay alert messaging, calling it imprecise and vague.She said: “Our assessment of the evidence leads me to conclude that the lockdown must be extended at this stage.“We know that progress remains fragile, our estimates suggest there are still signicant amounts of people in Scotland infected with this virus.Any signicant easing of restrictions at this stage would be very, very risky indeed.People in Scotland have not been allowed to spend leisure time outside and are only allowed to travel locally for exercise.Those measures were eased by Mr Johnson last week when he encouraged anyone who couldnt work from home to head back to work, and said people could travel to beauty spots and have picnics.The PMs statement caused a fracturing within the UK as devolved administrations refused to follow Englands lead.Welsh First Minister Mark Drakeford gave people a stern warning not to travel to Wales - saying they would be finedthey made non-essential travel.Ms Sturgeon is expected to lay out when Scottish children will be able to head back to schools.She has previously warned they may not be back behind desks until after the summer holidays.When asked about plans for English schools to reopen on June , Ms Sturgeon said she did not think it was the right thing to do.She said: I cannot and should not comment on whether that is title: mark zuckerberg facebook arms race election interference
story: The co-founder of the social network admitted his firm was unprepared for the state-sponsored propaganda which flooded the site in the  US election.In , Facebook was plunged into a political scandal when the data of  million of its users was sold to political consulting firm Cambridge Analytica.Zuckerberg, , who is the chairman and CEO of Facebook, says his organisation is now better prepared that any other company, and even some governments, to prevent attempts to influence politics.He told the BBC: “Countries are going to continue to try and interfere and we are going to see issues like that but we have learnt a lot since  and I feel pretty confident that we are going to be able to protect the integrity of the upcoming election.”Speaking in front of US Senators in , Zuckerberg said it was “entirely possible” data obtained by Cambridge Analytica could have been used by Russian operators attempting to influence the  race.He said: There are people in Russia whose job it is to try to exploit our systems and other internet systems and other systems as wellSo this is an arms race.Theyre going to keep getting better at this, and we need to invest in making sure we keep getting better at this too.”He then added that Facebook would have “more than , people” working on “security and content review” to prevent foreign agents exploiting the site.The Department of Homeland Security and the FBI warned states earlier this year that Russia could look to interfere in the  elections.According to a February  law enforcement memo obtained by the Associated Press, Moscow could meddle in the vote by covertly advising political candidates and campaigns.It says that though officials have not previously observed Moscow attempt this action against the US, political strategists working for a business mogul close to Vladimir Putin have been involved in political campaigning in African countries.The memo underscores how Trump administration officials are continuing to sound alarms about the prospect of future Russian interference even as Donald Trump has sought to downplay the Kremlins involvement in his  win.Because it was prepared before the coronavirus outbreak, the memo does not reflect how the pandemic might affect the tactics Russia might use to interfere with the election.GOT a story  EMAIL exclusive@the-sun Our journalists strive for accuracy title: only handful councils reopening schools head teachers
story: ONLY a handful of councils will reopen schools on June , leaving parents across the country in the dark over their childrens education.The final decision on whether or not to open up classrooms will fall to headteachers.According to a survey of  local authorities in England by The Times, only a small minority were willing to abide by Government advice.Almost two thirds of local authorities responded but only  of them said they would be planning afor June .Another  said they were leaving it up to inidual schools and headteachers and they would not lay out directions.Nine councils said they hadnt yet decided or did not provide a clear response.The Sun revealed  local authorities - with jurisdiction over , primary schools - were poised to defy the Governments advice and suggest that schools stay closed.Legally it is up to inidual schools and their governors to decide whether or not to reopen to students - but most primaries will seek direction from their local authority.The Prime Minister is keen to get children in reception, year one and year six back behind desks by June  so they can have at least a month of learning before the summer holiday.Government ministers have gone to great s to calm parents fears over their childrens safetythey head back to schools, and are caught in a huge row with teaching unions over protection of staff.Michael Tildesley, an associate professor at Warwick University who sits on the Government’s scientic advisory group for emergencies, said: “Cautiously, I think we’re in a position where we can start to think about opening schools in the next few weeks.But these relaxations need to be done gradually, you need to be monitoring it andnecessary prepare to reinstate lockdown measures, including schools closureswe do start to see cases rising.”Hardline unions have drawn up a list of  health and safety demands before teachers go back to class.One of the sticking points is having a robust contact tracing system in place - a move Mr Johnson said yesterday would be up and running by June .Many have said that Government advice to only allow class sizes of  pupils is still unworkable with social distancing.The British Medical Association, which represents doctors, dropped its hardline opposition to reopening.In a massive softening of its position, the BMA said schools can reopen on June  “as long as it is safe to do so”.It pointed out there is “growing evidence” the risk Covid- poses to kids is “extremely small”.Children’s commissioner Anne Longfield has told unions and ministers to “stop squabbling” and agree a plan to get kids back to class.Ministers and some of Labour’s big beasts, including Alan Johnson and David Blunkett, have warned poor kids are losing out the most from the schools shutdown. px,px, px" title: nurseries after lockdown uk
story: NURSERY kids will be able to play in smaller groups and hug staff after lockdown, the UK’s largest childcare provider said today.Some schools have suggested kids will have to play in hoops and stay inside markings on the playground as lockdown is eased.However, Busy Bees – which has  centres across the UK and Ireland – has confirmed its health and safety plans will not include those stringent measures.Kids will be able to play in smaller groups and teachers will work on iding children into close friendship groups to limit the number of people they come into contact with.They will also reduce the space that children can explore and increase the time they spend outdoors.Playdough, sandpits and water games will be banned in a bid to prevent the killer bug from spreading around nurseries.All children and staff will have their temperature checked upon arrival, and those families waiting to enter the nursery will be asked to wait two metres apart at drop off and pick up.Regular temperature checks for both children and team members will continue throughout the day, as will frequent handwashing and disinfecting of communal areas.Team members will be encouraged to cuddle childrenthey become upset during the day and to only wear face masks when temperature checks are being carried out.Earlier this week, the first pictures of how school could look for millions of children from next month was revealed - with children told to stand inside hoops to play in the playground.Holywell Village First School in Northumberland released pictures of their social distancing plans for when pupilsto classrooms on June .A photo demonstrating how this would look showed hula hoops lined across the playground and marked with an X.And one way systems will be in place inside corridors too to keep kids apart.Toys, soft furnishings and books have also been removed from classrooms, while outside play equipment will not be able to be used as there are not enough members of staff to clean it afterwards.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said both primary and secondary school pupils couldto school in just two weeks time, with plans for students in Reception and Years , ,  and  to .He also sought to reassure parents concerned about pupils ing to school, insisting that the governments decision-making is based on the best scientic advice with children at the very heart of everything we do.Busy Bees has kept over  of its centres open throughout the crisis to support key worker families and vulnerable children.Emily Brimson-Keight, Head of Safety at Busy Bees, said: “There is much speculation about how le after lockdown could look in nurseries and schools, and parents are understandably very anxious.“The biggest priority for us is, and always will be, the safety, welfare and happiness of the children in our care.“We are constantly sharing ideas and looking at best practice to ensure we can support the personal and emotional wellbeing for children and team members when they .“We’re committed to providing the best start in le for children, no matter the circumstances we find ourselves in.“Now the lockdown is set to be relaxed, we’re keen to offer assurance and debunk the myths about the new normal for parents at this unique time, and we are confident our plans ensure the safety and crucially, the development and happiness of children when we welcome them back.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time today coronavirus press briefing thursday may 21 speaking
story: A senior member of the Government will provide the update at pm, according to Downing Street.According to No, the coronavirus press briefing will be held today at pm.The conferences are usually held at Downing Street and also gives the press an opportunity to quiz the Government on its handling of the crisis.Since March , these updates have been a daily occurrence.It gives the media and public a chance to ask questions.Boris Johnson, the Prime Minister, or a senior member of the Government will chair the briefing.The aim of the conferences is to give updates on how ious departments of Government is dealing with the coronavirus outbreak in the country.Officials from ious communities including health, scientic and policing often co-chair, providing advice and information on how their departments is supporting the government in its bid tothe country to normal.The briefing follows reports that Boris Johnson is set to launch the new track and trace app by June .The app is intended to quickly identy new coronavirus sufferers in order to isolate them.Also, questions still remain whether schools will reopen on June , as suggested by the government.This comes after some unions and councils have criticised the Government’s date saying it is too soon.Travel is set to resume next month with Easyjet beginning operations next month, while following safety precautions.Meanwhile, the Government has cautioned the public not to purchase antibody tests which are not approved by Public Health England after Superdrug made tests available.The press briefing can be watched live on the BBC.You can also watch it on the Governments official YouTube page.Our coronavirus live blog will also provide updates on what is being said at the conference.On Wednesday, May , culture secretary, Oliver Dowden chaired the Government’s press conference alongside Professor Stephen Powis, England’s NHS National Director.In this update, Mr Dowden revealed that the Queen’s Birthday Honour’s List will be postponed to the autumn so people who are battling coronavirus can be recognised.This will include Captain Tom Moore who will receive a knighthood.Comic Relief, Children in Need and the National Emergencies Trust are also distributing £million of funds raised in the fight against the virus, according to the culture secretary.He also said £million will be allocated to get back to normal again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: key worker wins national lottery set for life
story: Rich and Kim Pearson, from Upminster, are finally able to buy their own home for themselves and rescue dog Loki after years of scrimping for a deposit.The couple, aged  and , have been forced to miss out on holidays and meals out while they saved - but can finally enjoy les luxuries after matching the five main numbers in the Set For Le draw on May .And they are also looking forward to celebrating after Rich, a key worker in the infrastructure sector, had to head off to a night sht after the win.Kim said: “For a couple of years we’ve put all the luxuries, like meals out and holidays, on hold so we could save for a deposit but when we saw Loki needed a home he became our essential, not luxury.We can’t help thinking that maybe fate decided to help give us a home because we’d given Loki his forever home.”Kim bought the winning ticket on a whim - and assumed she had maybe won a few quid when she received an email from Lottery bosses the next day.But she was stunned when she realised she had bagged £,-a-month for le - and ran upstairs to wake Richard, screaming: Weve won the Lottery.Rich said: “I had been working a night sht so was in the deepest sleep when Kim jumped on me.I had no idea what she was on about to begin with but it quickly sunk in when she showed me her phone and how much we’d won. It was certainly one of the more surreal starts to the day!”The pair confirmed the win with Camelot but were unable to celebrate at first as officer worker Kim needed to work and Rich had to get ready for another night sht.But Kim finally enjoyed the win with a glass of wine later that night.The couple are now looking forward to sharing their joy with family and friends once it is safe to do so in coronavirus lockdown.Kim said: This is a strange time to win because we haven’t been able to celebrate with those closest to us but when we safely can, that celebration will be all the sweeter.“We will definitely be treating everyone, and we may think about a holiday to see family in New Zealand but all that is some way off.So for now, we will keep ourselves safe, keep Loki entertained and out of mischief, and crack on with our house hunt.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: cyclone amphan worse coronavirus india bangladesh
story: Amphan barrelled in from the Bay of Bengal, lashing low lying coastal areas with ferocious wind and rain, as well as a ft high storm surge.It first hit the Sundarbans, a mangrove area around the India-Bangladesh border, that is home to four million people, before carving north and north-eastwards towards the city of Kolkata.In Bangladesh  deaths were reported, with  deaths in India’s West Bengal state, while a further two people were killed in India’s Odisha state.West Bengal Chief Minister Mamata Banerjee said most of them either electrocuted or killed by trees uprooted by winds of up to mph.She said the devastation in the state capital Kolkata, was a bigger disaster than Covid-.Area after area has been ruined. I have experienced a war-like situation today, she said.In Kolkata, home to more than  million people, large areas were underwater, including the city’s main airport.Roads were littered with uprooted trees and lamp posts while electricity and communication lines were down.Kolkata and its surrounding districts have been without electricity for a day.Trees uprooted, power supply snapped, lamp posts unhinged, glass panes in the locality shattered, internet connections flickered. Children screamed, resident Shamik Bag told the BBC.“Even with all doors and windows tightly shut, my house groaned under the pressure of the howling wind outside.“Within  minutes, the streets outside got flooded, even as flood waters rushed into the ground floor of homes.”Authorities in both countries managed to evacuate more than three million people, moving them to storm shelters before Amphan struck.But the evacuation effort was focused on communities that lay directly in the cyclones path, leaving villages on the flanks still vulnerable.The cyclone came at a time when the two countries are battling to stop the spread of the coronavirus.Some evacuees were initially reluctant to leave their homes for fear of possible infection in the packed storm shelters.I have never seen such a cyclone in my le,” Azgar Ali, , a resident of Satkhira district on the Bangladesh coast told Reuters.“It seemed like the end of the world. title: schools wont reopen until august scotland sturgeon
story: SCHOOLS in Scotland wont reopen until August and students will only be in classrooms part-time.First Minister Nicola Sturgeon announced today Scotlands roadmap to relax lockdown measures, stressing it would be done slowly and cautiously.Teachers and other school staff will begin ing to classrooms in June without students, so they are prepared to get kids learning in-person on a part-time basis.Ms Sturgeon said today: Teachers and other staff willduring June to prepare classrooms.On  August, all schools will reopen.Children willto a blended model with part time in school and part time at home.These arrangements will not represent a completeto normality but we judge them to be most sensible .This means Scottish students wont follow some English primary school pupils who are due to head back on June .But Scottish schools would break up for their summer holidays at the end of June and not head back until August based on a regular timetable.Ms Sturgeon set out a four phase approach to easing lockdown restrictions after Scotland refused to follow the PMs plan to relax measures earlier this month.Ms Sturgeons announcement comes as the UK has been fractured by dferent approaches to exiting lockdown.People in England have been allowed to spend leisure time outside since last week - but Scotland wont be able to sunbathe or spend more time outdoors until next week.Ms Sturgeon said the measures would begin to be brought in from May  but stressed that they were not in place yet.The UK Government has said people in England are allowed to socialise with other households but only with one person at a time, two metres apart.Ms Sturgeon said whole households will be able to mix in small groups as long as they are outdoors and two metres apart.Socialising: England: Schools England:Some primary classes to head back on June , starting with reception, year one and year six Leisure activity:England:The First Minister said: You will be able to sit or sunbathe in parks and open areas and you will be able to meet people from one other household, although initially in small numbers.Because of the much higher risk of indoor transmission visiting inside each others houses will not be permitted in phase one.The rules over socialising will be laxer in Scotland - as people will be able to visit one another in gardens.The roadmap says: We are planning in this phase to change regulations to permit people to use public outdoor spaces for recreational purposes, for example to sit in a public space.We are also planning for one household to meet up with another household outdoors, in small numbers, including in gardens, but with physical distancing required.Nicola Sturgeons roadmap for exiting lockdown Ms Sturgeon said the R number - or rate of transmission of coronavirus - is between . and  in Scotland, and measures would only be relaxedthe number stayed below .She said: In Marchwas probably above .Progress remains fragile and it would be too easy for the virus to run out of control again.Although we estimate that the R number is below , there is still uncertainty over how far below, we have some confidence that the R number has been below  for more than three weeks.In my judgement the time is right to move towards a careful relaxation of lockdown restrictions.No said this lunchtime: We welcome todays announcements as it title: scotland visit family friends 2m fistance
story: BORIS Johnson is today under pressure to relax more lockdown rules in England - after it emerged that they would have less freedom to meet up than in Scotland and Northern Ireland.As part of her plan to ease the lockdown, it will mean that anyone can meet with people from one other household, outdoors.That can even be in each others gardens, the new Scottish plan said today.But it will only happenthe scientic advice says the R rate of transmission is still under control, she said.She told Scotland this lunchtime: You will be able to sit or sunbathe in parks and open areas, and you will be able to meet people from one other household, though initially in small numbers, while you are outside.This is a change which we hope will benefit everyone, but particularly those without gardens, and people who live on their own.However it is important to stress that dferent households should remain two metres apart from each other – that is critical in ensuring that this change doesn’t provide the virus with easy routes of transmission.The change means the rules will be dferent to England, where only two people are allowed to meet outside at one time - and they must stay two metres apart.And people in England are allowed to meet up with people from other households too - they do not have to just pick one.Ms Sturgeons announcement comes as the UK has been fractured by dferent approaches to exiting lockdown.People in England have been allowed to spend leisure time outside since last week - but Scotland wont be able to sunbathe or spend more time outdoors until next week.And in Northern Ireland, up to six people can meet up outside at one time.Ms Sturgeon set out a four phase approach to easing lockdown restrictions after Scotland refused to follow the PMs plan to relax measures.Her plan included:Teachers and other school staff will begin ing to classrooms in June, without students, so they are prepared to get kids learning on a part-time basis.Ms Sturgeon said today: Teachers and other staff willduring June to prepare classrooms.On  August, all schools will reopen.Children willto a blended model with part in school and part time at home.These arrangements will not represent a completeto normality but we judge them to be most sensible .This means Scottish students wont follow some English primary school pupils who are due to head by on June .But Scottish schools break up for their summer holidays at the end of June and do not head back until August based on a regular timetable.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uk reject eu border post demand
story: Government documents published on Wednesday confirmed there will need to be checks on some goods entering Northern Ireland from the rest of the UK from January next year once the Brexit transition period has ended.But it rejected the EU’s demands for new infrastructure to be introduced to carry out the checks. Instead they will expand existing border screening to carry out the additional checks.And the government documents made clear that the checks will be conducted by UK border officials, snubbing EU demands to have their own personnel carrying out checks.It set up another big row with Brussels, which wanted to install a permanent base in Northern Ireland to oversee the checks.But Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove, who unveiled the UK plans in the Commons on Wednesday, admitted that Northern Ireland will have to follow EU rules on agriculture and manufactured goods until at least .The key concession will ensure access to the EU’s single market and keep the border with the Republic of Ireland free-flowing in order to maintain the Northern Ireland Peace Agreement.The Government paper said having a so-called “mini-EU embassy” in Belfast would be “isive” and called on Brussels to “respect the UK’s territorial integrity”.It also promised Northern Ireland businesses would benefit from “unfettered access” when selling goods to the rest of the UK. It ended a row over whether checks would be in place on goods entering the UK from Northern Ireland.Mr Gove, minister in charge of Brexit preparations, said: Our proposals will deliver unfettered access for Northern Ireland businesses to the whole of the UK market ensure there are no tarfs on goods remaining within the UK customs territory discharge our obligations without the need for any new customs infrastructure in Northern Ireland and, finally, guarantee that Northern Ireland businesses benefit from the lower tarfs we deliver through our new free trade agreements with third countries.The plans were given a cautious initial welcome by the EU last night, who said they will be monitoring the implementation of the Northern Ireland Protocol closely.A European Commission spokesman said: “The detailed legal commitments set out in the Protocol must now be implemented precisely to give full effect to this solution.The time to implement the Protocol is short, and practical implementation measures must start immediately so that the Protocol can be operational by  January . To this end, the Commission stands ready to work with the UK authorities.”In a further sign of relations souring between the two sides, the EU’s chief negotiator Michel Barnier last night hit out at the “tone” of his opposite number David Frost.He said a “new dynamism” was needed in talksthe two sides are to avoid a “stalemate”.Mr Barnier was hitting back at a furious letter from Mr Frost that was highly critical of the EU’s rigid approach to the negotiations.Mr Frost said Brussels proposed deal contains novel and unbalanced proposals which would bind this country to EU law or standards.He said: What is on offer is not a fair free trade relationship between close economic partners, but a relatively low-quality trade agreement coming with unprecedented EU oversight of our laws and institutions.”In his reply, Mr Barnier said he did not think an exchange of letters regarding the substance of the negotiations is necessarily the best way to discuss on substantial points.He added: It cannot be a substitute for serious engagement and detailed negotiations and, in particular, I would not like the tone that you have taken to impact the mutual trust and constructive attitude that is essential between us.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. Opposition MPs failed in a bid to block the plan for the ‘virtual Parliament’ to be abandoned in a vote last night. This morning, Henry Smith, the Conservative MP for Crawley, tweeted: “Not that I should be surprised by the lazy left but interesting how work-shy socialist and nationalist MPs tried to keep the remote Parliament going beyond  June.” His comments were met with fury from readers, some of whom asked whether he considered all home workers lazy. Others asked whether his comments reflected his own home-working practices. Former Labour MP Liz McInnes said: “Donapost you do any work in your constituency, Henry “Enjoy your recess then - nothing at all to do. The people of Crawley must be so grateful to have you.” And Shadow Exchequer Secretary Wes Streeting said: “If you think that the virtual Parliament and home-working has been a aposwork-shyapos or aposlazyapos experience, then that tells us rather more about how youaposve been spending your working days in recent weeks than the rest of us whoaposve been working flat out.” Labour’s Lloyd Russel-Moyle said: “Henry this is totally below you. We were on a call together on Gatwick yesterday, the fact that you and I did that from our home - was that not work  “The [Government] guidelines isyou can work from home you should - why are you keen to make it impossible to keep working safely.” The Prime Minister’s official spokesman said Tory leader Boris Johnson would not have been aware of the comments, and that he had not discussed it with him.Our focus has been on ensuring Parliament can perform all of its key s. One of those is scrutiny, another is legislation and MPs not being able to work from the House of Commons certainly has led to problems in terms of being able to scrutinise legislation.

The Skyrora completed a full ground static fire trial with the Skylark-L – the UK’s first vertical test of this magnitude since the Black Arrow Programme in the late s and early s. The need for social distancing brought extra challenges, “all of which were handled expertly by all the team” said Skyrora boss Volodymyr Levykin. He added: “This was a mammoth effort in very trying circumstances, so it is quite an achievement to be proud of.” After the successful test at Kildemorie Estate near Alness, close to the Cromarty Firth, the Skylark-L could be ready to launch from a British spaceport as early as next spring. story: NewsBritish Magaluf bar worker, , found dead in her home near party stripDanielle Finlay Brookes was discovered dead on Tuesday night at her flat in an apartment block near the brash Punta Ballena strip. Friends have described her as a girl "full of fun and laughter"ShareCommentsByGerard Couzens:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsDanielle Finlay Brookes was discovered dead on Tuesday night at her flat in an apartment block near the famous Magaluf resort’s beach " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British Magaluf bar worker was reportedly found dead inside a wardrobe at her home near the famous party resort. Danielle Finlay Brookes, , was discovered dead on Tuesday night at her flat in an apartment block near the brash Punta Ballena strip. Local reports said she had been discovered leless inside a wardrobe at the property before police arrived after a concerned neighbour managed to get in. Police could not be reached early this morning for an official comment but it is understood Danielle’s death is not being treated as suspicious at this stage. Well-wishers have already donated nearly £, towards a GoFundMe appeal set up to raise money towards repatriation and funeral costs. One of the two expats who set up the fundraising site is Meghan Tattersall, who was badly hurt in a hate-fuelled hit-and-run in Magaluf in May  when she was mowed down by the ex-girlfriend of her new partner. Kemi Coaker, , from Manchester, was handed a two-year suspended jail sentence in May last year after confessing to running over Meghan, , from Leeds, after a plea bargain deal. Sales rep Meghan said in a Facebook tribute on Wednesday: “Your are my best friend and my angel high in the sky. I’m truly heartbroken. “I’m so proud to be able to spend everyday with you. Fly high my princess. RIP to my girl I’m so proud of. I love you.” [sic] Another pal, Jay Burton, said of the tragic expat, originally from Crewe, Cheshire: “Absolutely devastated to hear the news Danielle Finlay Brookes. “You were the le of the party everywhere you were. Hope you rest in peace. Magaluf won’t be the same without you.” He added in a later post: “Sending all my love to everyone  who is struggling through this tough time. “Being stuck indoors, with your mind doing somersaults, thinking you’re not good enough, with the biggest challenge of the day being putting a smile on your face.  “Thinking no-one would careyou just didn’t wake up the next day. “Today seeing all the support from the Maga family after losing an amazing girl who cared for everyone, makes me realise how le is too short and many people actually do care. “To all my friends and family, please check on those you haven’t heard from in a while.” Danielle, who described herself on social media as a “Queen building her own empire” had worked in Magaluf for several years. She is thought to have lived alone. She was described as a worker at the Three Lions Karaoke bar in October  when she filmed Spanish police hitting a female tourist as she tried to break up a fight between two men. She wrote alongside the footage, which was posted on a Facebook page for Magaluf residents: “Spanish Guardia for you - attacking a girl for no reason.” She later wrote an impassioned statement about the incident, moaning Brits in the party resort were treated worse than muggers and prostitutes she claimed were “free to roam the streets.” Emotional pal Rob Dury said: “No words can describe how much all your friends and family will miss that smile. “A beautul young woman taken too soon. Thanks for being you. I will miss your hugs and chats.” The latest tragedy comes just less than a month after the death of another much-loved Magaluf bar worker, -year-old Irishman Anthony Ennis.  He plunged to his death from his eighth-floor apartment in the party resort just after am on April . Anthony, believed to be from Waterville, Co Kerry, worked at the well-known Stereo Bar in Magaluf. He was described as a “diamond of a bloke” by one friend after it emerged he had died. The results of an investigation into his death have not been made public but police are not understood to be treating the incident as a crime. Like Danielle, popular Anthony was gearing up for a much quieter season this year because of the coronavirus crisis. Brits normally make up most of the holidaymakers flocking to Magaluf and its raucous Punta Ballena party strip in the peak summer season months. But local tourism chiefs have predicted they could be outnumbered by other nationalities including Spaniards and Germans this yeara feared UK quarantine keeps them away.

The glorious weather continues for most of the UK today after yesterday was recorded as the warmest day of the year so far. The mercury climbed to .Cnear Heathrow Airport on Wednesday, as sunbathers across England enjoyed new found-freedom following the easing of lockdown restrictions. Londonaposs St Jamesaposs Park recorded a high of .Con Tuesday - beating aposs previous top of Cset last month. But the good weather is clearly testing the nationaposs resolve when it comes to sticking to social distancing measures. Some authorities said valuable resources were being used to police traffic and people jumped in the cars and headed to the coast or beauty spots. Follow all coronavirus updates on our live blog here Officers in Ilfracombe and Braunton said they had identied vehicles from all over the country in the local area, where toilets and other amenities remain closed. Roads towards the North Devon coast are now gridlocked, officers tweeted. We have vehicles from all over the country identied, please do not travel here. We will still be here when this is over so come back when itaposs safe to do so. Some of the UKaposs beaches were a magnet for sunseekers - with Southend Beach in Essex particularly packed with visitors from as far away as Manchester and Leicestershire.And the tourists - who have been blasted by local councillors as foolish and irresponsible - have left behind piles of rubbish, including Tesco bags, boxes of Corona beer, and plastic toys. Southend councillors have said they now fear for the safety of visitors ahead of a potentially scorching Bank Holiday weekend this weekend. Matt Dent, Labour councillor for Kursaal, blasted those travelling long distances to enjoy the seaside and warned of a potential second spikethe behaviour continues. He said: The more I see of this, the more I fear weaposre in for a second wave. It isnapost Southend residents, itaposs people travelling from outside the borough - as far away as Manchester, from what Iaposve heard - who seem to think lockdown is lted, and Covid- is no longer a threat. It is a small minority who are acting in this foolish and irresponsible manner. But their behaviour impacts on all of us ultimately,there is a resurgence in infections and we find ourselves facing a second, longer, far stricter lockdown through the summer and into the autumn. Meanwhile, Labour council leader Ian Gilbert echoed his warnings, and added: I do have concerns about the weekend. We want our open spaces to be safe and enjoyed.  I am worried we could see an influx of visitors and we donapost want to see social distancing break down. I think itaposs being managed as well as we can at the moment. Their warnings come as the promenade between Chalkwell and Southend Pier has been temporarily widened to keep people socially distant while using the seafront.

title: im helping key workers work
story: NewsIm helping other key workers get to work - but Im terried of making my family sickDan Boyns is an Arriva bus driver in Gillingham, and he now spends his days taking NHS staff and other essential staff to fight coronavirus on the front line. Hes spoken toas part of our Frontline Fighters series, where we discover what its really like to be a key worker during the pandemicShareCommentsByZoe ForseyLestyle Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsDan Boyns" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailDan Boynsaposs bus used to be filled with people going shopping, heading out to see friends or visiting family, but now itaposs just key workers stepping onboard.He takes NHS staff to hospital so they can save the lives of coronavirus patients, supermarket staff to stores so people can buy food, and teachers to schools so they can look after children.Heaposs also a key worker, and his decision to continue going out to work every day means hundreds of others can do the same. When lockdown was introduced and Dan, who works for Arriva and is based at the Gillingham Depot, knew he wanted to carry on driving, but he admits heaposs terried about bringing the virus back to his family.Speaking to theas part of our Frontline Fighters series, he said: I was happy to stay at work, working helps me provide for the family. I don’t feel like part of a big fight I just do the job I love. I don’t class myself as key worker, and I have never felt so appreciated nor realised how much the service I provide helps people. When customers get on and off buses the thank you is more heartfelt that before. I never considered quitting, I love my job. While Dan says Arriva have done everything they can to keep drivers and have been very supportive, he is still worried about getting coronavirus and taking it home to his we and five daughters.  He said: The most dficult part for me is knowing I could potentially bring something home to my family. I feel safe when driving, Arriva have done a lot to help protect me. I don’t feel like I am at more risk, I still do the same job I love. Because I am still at work personally it does not feel like anything has changed.Dan one some of his colleagues have taken to dressing up on their shts to try and make passengers smile.
